comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -523,6 +530,9 @@ associated with patterns:
     node's entire text should be re-parsed, including the text of its child
     nodes. By default, child nodes' text will be excluded from the injected
     document.
+    • `injection.self` - indicates that the node's text should be parsed with

comment_data.body: It's somewhat intentional - one's for `@injection.self`, the other `(#set! injection.self)`

comment_data.body: What's the rationale for the duplication upstream here (and not for self.parent)? Do we need to support (officially, documented) both?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -523,6 +530,9 @@ associated with patterns:
     node's entire text should be re-parsed, including the text of its child
     nodes. By default, child nodes' text will be excluded from the injected
     document.
+    • `injection.self` - indicates that the node's text should be parsed with

comment_data.body:
I made `injection.self` apply for both the capture and set directive key for consistency w/ `injection.language`

But since we know the language in the self/parent instances either way, I could remove the set directive version (or the capture) since it is redundant, or add the directive for parent for consistency
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -523,6 +530,9 @@ associated with patterns:
     node's entire text should be re-parsed, including the text of its child
     nodes. By default, child nodes' text will be excluded from the injected
     document.
+    • `injection.self` - indicates that the node's text should be parsed with

comment_data.body:
I think it's better to support only one way of doing things, unless there's a good use case for both.

I personally don't have much of a preference which (probably the directive is more consistent); the main thing is to be consistent with upstream in order to be able to share queries more easily.
(Of course, that means if upstream supports both, we need to as well -- grudgingly.)

@lewis6991 ?

@@ -523,6 +530,9 @@ associated with patterns:
     node's entire text should be re-parsed, including the text of its child
     nodes. By default, child nodes' text will be excluded from the injected
     document.
+    • `injection.self` - indicates that the node's text should be parsed with

comment_data.body: I agree with only directives, as captures here may be confusing in usage. Should it be placed where `injection.language` should be, or should it be similar to nvim-treesitter's old `@{lang}`, replacing `injection.content` ? Both are reasonable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -523,6 +530,9 @@ associated with patterns:
     node's entire text should be re-parsed, including the text of its child
     nodes. By default, child nodes' text will be excluded from the injected
     document.
+    • `injection.self` - indicates that the node's text should be parsed with

comment_data.body:
I think I see why Max structured it as such for injections specifically - captures are only meant to be used if the node's text is relevant to the injection, else you're just wasting space in the fields of the HighlightConfiguration (hence why you read the string content of the directive's key dynamically)

So, content and language are relevant (one for the text to parse, one to check the content of to know which language to inject)
